content.title: Theoretical Minimum Momentum
content.abstract: Momentum has no theoretical minimum - it is a continuous quantity that can be zero. However, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle constrains simultaneous knowledge of position and momentum, and in finite systems there's a minimum momentum related to the system size.

theoretical_minimum.absolute: p = 0 is allowed (particle at rest in its reference frame)
theoretical_minimum.in_finite_box: p_min = h/(2L) for box of size L

classical_theory.continuity: Momentum is continuous, can take any value

uncertainty_principle.implication: Cannot have both Δx → 0 and Δp → 0
uncertainty_principle.interpretation: Not a minimum momentum, but minimum uncertainty product

particle_in_box.interpretation: Standing wave condition quantizes momentum in confined systems

photon_momentum.cosmic_limit: Photon with λ = universe size: p ~ 10⁻⁶¹ kg⋅m/s

massive_particle_at_rest.zero_point_momentum: In confined systems, zero-point motion gives minimum |p|
massive_particle_at_rest.example: Ground state of harmonic oscillator: ⟨p²⟩ = mℏω/2

de_broglie_wavelength.interpretation: As p → 0, λ → ∞ (delocalized over all space)
de_broglie_wavelength.implication: Very low momentum = very long wavelength

finite_universe_limit.interpretation: Momentum resolution limited by universe size (IR cutoff)

comparison_with_planck.insight: This is macroscopic! A walking person has similar momentum.
